title: What Are Points and Miles?
excerpt: Understand the loyalty currencies airlines and hotels use, how they differ, and why transferable points matter.
seoTitle: What Are Points and Miles? | Miles Go Round
seoDescription: Learn the basics of airline miles, hotel points, and transferable currencies so you can start earning them intentionally.

sections.heading: The currencies behind your trips
body: Airlines and hotels reward loyalty with their own currencies—miles and points—that can be exchanged for flights, stays, and upgrades instead of cash.
Banks also offer transferable points that can be sent to multiple partners, making them more flexible than a single airline or hotel balance.

sections.heading: How value is measured
body: Point values aren’t fixed. Some programs peg points to cash prices, while others use award charts that can unlock outsized value on the right routes or dates.
Tracking your personal cents-per-point target helps you decide when to redeem and when to pay cash.

sections.heading: Transferable vs. co-branded
body: Transferable points from banks keep your options open because you can move them to many airlines or hotels when you find award space.
Co-branded cards earn points with a single program. They’re great for specific perks like free checked bags or elite-night credits.

title: How to Earn Points and Miles
excerpt: See the fastest ways to build balances with cards, shopping portals, dining programs, and limited-time bonuses.
seoDescription: From welcome offers to stacking shopping portals, here are practical ways to earn more miles and points every month.

sections.heading: Start with welcome offers
body: Credit card welcome bonuses are the quickest way to earn a large stash. Map spending to meet the requirement without unnecessary purchases.
Set calendar reminders for annual fees and bonus deadlines so you never miss easy points.

sections.heading: Stack everyday spending
body: Use dining and shopping portals that layer on extra points when you click through their links before buying online or dining out.
Category bonuses on your cards—like groceries, travel, or dining—can double or triple your earnings on repeat expenses.

sections.heading: Look for partner promos
body: Limited-time transfer bonuses or partner promotions can boost your totals by 10–40% and help you top up a partner balance faster.
Always compare the promo timeline with your travel plans so you don’t move points into a program you won’t use soon.

title: How to Redeem Miles for Maximum Value
excerpt: Learn the steps to find award space, compare partners, and decide when to save or spend your miles.
seoTitle: Redeem Miles the Smart Way | Miles Go Round
seoDescription: A beginner-friendly workflow to search award space, compare taxes and fees, and stretch every mile.

sections.heading: Search with partners first
body: Many alliances let you book flights on partner airlines. Searching on a partner site can reveal saver awards that don’t appear on your home airline.
When you find availability, check multiple partners to compare taxes, fees, and surcharges before transferring points.

sections.heading: Know your sweet spots
body: Fixed award charts and distance-based programs often hide sweet spots—like short-haul business class or off-peak awards—that deliver better value than cash fares.
Keep a shortlist of routes you fly often and track their award prices so you can act quickly when space opens.

sections.heading: When to pay cash instead
body: If a flight is inexpensive or heavily taxed, paying cash and saving your points for a premium redemption can be smarter.
Use a baseline value per point to decide. If the redemption value is below your target, pay cash and keep earning.

title: Managing Multiple Loyalty Accounts
excerpt: Stay organized with account tracking, activity reminders, and a plan for expirations and family pooling.

sections.heading: Track balances in one place
body: Use a simple spreadsheet or app to log balances, account numbers, and expiration dates so nothing slips through the cracks.
Note which programs reset expiration with activity and which do not, then set reminders 60 days before a deadline.

sections.heading: Protect your accounts
body: Enable two-factor authentication and unique passwords for every loyalty account—takeovers are more common than you’d think.
Add authorized users strategically to help track family travel but avoid sharing logins when you can use pooling features instead.

sections.heading: Keep points flexible
body: Transfer points only when you’re ready to book. Until then, keep them with the bank so you can pivot if plans change.
When you do transfer, screenshot confirmations and set a short reminder to verify the points arrived before searching again.
